articles.headline: Outsider Tapped in Flynn Case Calls Justice Dept. Reversal a ‘Gross Abuse’ of Power
articles.snippet: A former federal judge said that the attorney general gave special treatment to a presidential ally, undermining public confidence in the rule of law.
articles.abstract: A former federal judge said that the attorney general gave special treatment to a presidential ally, undermining public confidence in the rule of law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A retired federal judge accused the Justice Department on Wednesday of a “gross abuse of prosecutorial power” and urged a court to reject its attempt to drop the criminal case against Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Leading Foundations Pledge to Give More, Hoping to Upend Philanthropy
articles.snippet: The Ford Foundation and four others plan to substantially increase their spending, a splurge financed in part by issuing debt.
articles.abstract: The Ford Foundation and four others plan to substantially increase their spending, a splurge financed in part by issuing debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: The week after the U.S. economy shut down in March, Darren Walker, the president of the Ford Foundation, fielded a stream of phone calls from the heads of dozens of organizations that Ford supports. Many were panicked. One was in tears.
articles.byline: By James B. Stewart and Nicholas Kulish

articles.headline: Aggressive Tactics by National Guard, Ordered to Appease Trump, Wounded the Military, Too
articles.snippet: Some members of the D.C. Guard — comprising more than 60 percent people of color — have not told family they were part of the crackdown. Guard leadership, concerned about public opposition, even warned against buying food from vendors.
articles.abstract: Some members of the D.C. Guard — comprising more than 60 percent people of color — have not told family they were part of the crackdown. Guard leadership, concerned about public opposition, even warned against buying food from vendors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A white National Guard commander called the standoff in Lafayette Square “the Alamo,” implying that the White House was under siege. Black members of the D.C. Guard objected to turning on their neighbors. Army leaders told pilots to “flood the box with everything we have” as two helicopters buzzed protesters in the streets.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Adidas Pledges to Increase Diversity. Some Employees Want More.
articles.snippet: The sportswear company has been facing dissension owing to what some say is an internal culture that can be discriminating toward black workers.
articles.abstract: The sportswear company has been facing dissension owing to what some say is an internal culture that can be discriminating toward black workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last two days, the sportswear giant Adidas has made several promises to black employees.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Kevin Draper

articles.headline: Fed Leaves Rates Unchanged and Projects Years of High Unemployment
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve officials indicated they expected the economic recovery from the pandemic-induced recession to be a slow one, with rates near zero for years.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve officials indicated they expected the economic recovery from the pandemic-induced recession to be a slow one, with rates near zero for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The head of the Federal Reserve on Wednesday offered a grim assessment of how quickly the U.S. economy will recover from its pandemic-induced recession, suggesting that millions of people could remain out of work for an extended period as central bank officials estimated unemployment will be at 9.3 percent by the end of 2020.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: China’s Street Vendor Push Ignites a Debate: How Rich Is It?
articles.snippet: The premier’s suggestion to empower a “stall economy” and focus on low-income workers leads some to ask whether the world’s No. 2 economy is as prosperous as it seems.
articles.abstract: The premier’s suggestion to empower a “stall economy” and focus on low-income workers leads some to ask whether the world’s No. 2 economy is as prosperous as it seems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Xie Yiyi lost her job last Friday, making the 22-year-old Beijing resident one of millions of young people in China left unmoored and shaken by the coronavirus.

articles.headline: Joe Biden, Emissary of Grief
articles.snippet: His entire political career has been marked by personal loss. His allies say that makes him uniquely capable of leading a nation grappling with death.
articles.abstract: His entire political career has been marked by personal loss. His allies say that makes him uniquely capable of leading a nation grappling with death.
articles.lead_paragraph: An overstuffed binder sat in Joe Biden’s Senate office, holding the raw materials of his grief.
articles.byline: By Katie Glueck and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: As Energy Prices Tumble, Developing Countries Trim Subsidies
articles.snippet: Trying to cut spending as the pandemic reduces tax revenue, governments are finding it easier to lift restraints on what consumers pay for fuel.
articles.abstract: Trying to cut spending as the pandemic reduces tax revenue, governments are finding it easier to lift restraints on what consumers pay for fuel.
articles.lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has sent economies into recession and reduced government revenue, so some countries are taking a politically perilous path: removing restraints on electricity and petroleum prices.

articles.headline: One Bar. Twelve Weeks. Seventeen Lives in Lockdown.
articles.snippet: Following an Oakland tavern and its staff — from the tattooed bartender to the undocumented cleaner — as they weather the economic and emotional fallout of the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: Following an Oakland tavern and its staff — from the tattooed bartender to the undocumented cleaner — as they weather the economic and emotional fallout of the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Cold beer flowed, soul music played and regulars lined the redwood bar to order tequila shots and tater tots. No one wore masks, many hugged, and the staff passed a joint out front.

articles.headline: Sobering Jobs Outlook: ‘We’re Expecting a Long Haul’
articles.snippet: More than 1.5 million sought state unemployment benefits last week as layoffs spread to more job categories even as businesses reopened.
articles.abstract: More than 1.5 million sought state unemployment benefits last week as layoffs spread to more job categories even as businesses reopened.
articles.lead_paragraph: Although workers have begun returning to restaurants, retailers and other businesses hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic, layoffs are seeping through sections of the job market that previously escaped major damage.

articles.headline: Milley Apologizes for Role in Trump Photo Op: ‘I Should Not Have Been There’
articles.snippet: President Trump’s walk across Lafayette Square, current and former military leaders say, has started a moment of reckoning in the military.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s walk across Lafayette Square, current and former military leaders say, has started a moment of reckoning in the military.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The country’s top military official apologized on Thursday for taking part in President Trump’s walk across Lafayette Square for a photo op after the authorities used tear gas and rubber bullets to clear the area of peaceful protesters.

articles.headline: Amazon Set to Face Antitrust Charges in European Union
articles.snippet: The European Commission plans to bring charges that Amazon abused its dominance in e-commerce.
articles.abstract: The European Commission plans to bring charges that Amazon abused its dominance in e-commerce.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — European Union officials are preparing to bring antitrust charges against Amazon for abusing its dominance in internet commerce to box out smaller rivals, according to people with knowledge of the case.

articles.headline: Federal Arrests Show No Sign That Antifa Plotted Protests
articles.snippet: Despite claims by President Trump and Attorney General William P. Barr, there is scant evidence that loosely organized anti-fascists are a significant player in protests.
articles.abstract: Despite claims by President Trump and Attorney General William P. Barr, there is scant evidence that loosely organized anti-fascists are a significant player in protests.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inciting a riot. Hurling a Molotov cocktail. Plotting to sow destruction. Those are some of the most serious charges brought by federal prosecutors against demonstrators at protests across the country in recent weeks.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar, Alan Feuer and Adam Goldman
